# Steps to reproduce

```powershell

```

# Expected behavior

```none

```

# Actual behavior

``'
Warning: PowerShell detected that you might be using a screen reader and has disabled PSReadLine for compatibility purposes. If you want to re-enable it, run 'Import-Module PSReadLine'.
```

# Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```none
C:\Users\Tim> $PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.0.0
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.0.0
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.18363
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0

C:\Users\Tim>
```

I'm not aware that I am using any screen reader.

If PowerShell is going to automatically disable features based on a probabilistic detection ("you *might* be using a screen reader") then at the very least, could it state what screen reader it thinks I may be using so that I have half a chance of sorting it out?

Ideally, I would prefer it if PowerShell printed a warning and told me how to disable PSReadLine, rather than automatically (and wrongly) disabling it.

comments.body: Really PowerShell says that it can not _load_ PSReadline. We would only reword the warning message.
